title: BOJ's Ueda Projects Tight Labor Market Barring Major Shock

content:
JACKSON HOLE, Wyoming (Reuters) -Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said on Saturday the country's labor market is expected to remain tight barring a major negative demand shock, and expects upward pressure on wages.

Despite a dwindling working-age population, wage growth remained stagnant for decades in Japan due to "entrenched deflationary expectations" that discouraged companies from raising prices and pay, Ueda said.

Now, wages are rising and labor shortages have become "one of our most pressing economic issues," as global inflation caused by the COVID-19 pandemic served as an external shock that broke Japan out of a deflationary equilibrium, he said.

"Notably, wage growth is spreading from large enterprises to small and medium enterprises," Ueda said in a panel held during the Federal Reserve's annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

"Barring a major negative demand shock, the labor market is expected to remain tight and continue to exert upward pressure on wages," he said in the panel that addressed labor market challenges developing in major economies.
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOE) Governor Kazuo Ueda has stated that the country's labor market is expected to remain tight, without a major negative demand shock, and that wages are rising. This comes as global inflation caused by the COVID-19 pandemic led to Japan breaking out of a deflationary equilibrium. Ueda stated that wage growth is increasing, shifting from large businesses to small ones.
shortSummary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda predicted a tight labor market with rising wages, despite recent criticism of the situation.
argos_summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said at the Jackson Hole conference that Japan’s labor market will stay tight unless a major negative demand shock occurs, and that this will continue to push wages higher. He noted that after decades of stagnant wages due to deflationary expectations, the recent global inflation shock has spurred wage growth across both large and small firms. Ueda highlighted labor shortages as a pressing issue and emphasized that the upward wage pressure is likely to persist in the near term.
